title: Notable & Quotable: The Media’s Addiction
sub_head: ‘Praise from anti-Trump celebrities on Twitter has become like a “narcotic” for some.’
body:
McKay Coppinswriting for the Atlantic, Dec. 29:

The day after the 2016 election, I got a phone call from an old friend. Neither of us had slept much, and we spent most of the conversation exchanging shell-shocked comments of the Can you believe this? variety. Before we hung up, his voice took on a trace of irony. “Well,” he said, “this is going to be great for your career.” . . . One cable-news anchor told me that praise from anti-Trump celebrities on Twitter has become like a “narcotic” for some of his colleagues. “It’s important to people that George Takei likes their monologue,” the anchor said, requesting anonymity to speak candidly about his peers (and presumably to avoid alienating George Takei).
